abstract.p: Prof Lawrence Kemper letter disputes Brent Staples's June 23 Editorial Observer column on California's public school system

block.p: Brent Staples's June 23 Editorial Observer, ''The Mississippification of California Schools,'' has much truth in it. However, the problem is far more complex than Proposition 13, a lack of investment and certified teachers.

Demographics of students have changed greatly in the last 20 years. Sixty percent of California children speak a language other than English. The fads presented to California teachers have increasingly been at the direction of a state political bureaucracy that changes its preferences with the wind.

Brent Staples's June 23 Editorial Observer, ''The Mississippification of California Schools,'' has much truth in it. However, the problem is far more complex than Proposition 13, a lack of investment and certified teachers.

Demographics of students have changed greatly in the last 20 years. Sixty percent of California children speak a language other than English. The fads presented to California teachers have increasingly been at the direction of a state political bureaucracy that changes its preferences with the wind.

Policy Analysis for California Education is correct when it urges a moratorium on further political ''help.'' The state needs to allow local districts to meet their own challenges in ways that involve local parents and teachers.
LAWRENCE KEMPER La Verne, Calif., June 23, 2000
The writer is an associate professor of educational management at the University of La Verne.
